head.title: Word for Word/Pop Quiz; History 101: Snoop Doggy Roosevelt

hedline.hl1: Word for Word/Pop Quiz; History 101: Snoop Doggy Roosevelt

abstract.p: Over 500 college seniors at 55 leading colleges and universities take test comprised of 34 high-school level history questions; results are dismal: only one student answers all questions correctly, and average score is 53 percent; none of schools examined require American history courses for graduation; test detailed (M)

block.p: LISTEN up, class. We hate to spoil your holiday weekend, but an alarming new survey of American history knowledge 2/3-- released just days before Independence Day, no less 2/3 -- suggests that the nation is in desperate need of summer school. The report, sponsored by the American Council of Trustees and Alumni, a Washington-based nonprofit group that promotes liberal-arts study, posed 34 high-school level questions randomly to 556 seniors at 55 leading colleges and universities, including Harvard, Princeton and Brown.

Only one student answered all the questions correctly, and the average score was a sobering 53 percent -- even with a couple of gimmes about cartoon characters and rap stars tossed in. But maybe it's not too surprising: according to the survey, none of the schools examined require American history courses for graduation.

LISTEN up, class. We hate to spoil your holiday weekend, but an alarming new survey of American history knowledge 2/3-- released just days before Independence Day, no less 2/3 -- suggests that the nation is in desperate need of summer school. The report, sponsored by the American Council of Trustees and Alumni, a Washington-based nonprofit group that promotes liberal-arts study, posed 34 high-school level questions randomly to 556 seniors at 55 leading colleges and universities, including Harvard, Princeton and Brown.

Only one student answered all the questions correctly, and the average score was a sobering 53 percent -- even with a couple of gimmes about cartoon characters and rap stars tossed in. But maybe it's not too surprising: according to the survey, none of the schools examined require American history courses for graduation.
So put down those tube steaks and sharpen your pencils. It's time to match wits with tomorrow's leaders.
